title: Japinat
author: Japinat
content: Be careful with job offers, especially those coming from unsolicited text messages. There’s a new report about a scheme that has scammed people out of $2 million from various victims.According to the report, scammers target people by sending unsolicited texts offering jobs with attractive compensation and commissions. However, before starting, they require victims to set up a wallet address and fund it with crypto, supposedly as a form of security. They promise that the funds can be withdrawn along with the commission later on.Unfortunately, the victims didn’t realize that everything was happening on the scammers’ website. As a result, all the crypto funds they deposited ended up in the scammers’ wallets.For the full details of the news, you can read it here.  Text messaging scammers stole $2M in cryptocurrency from victims, NY attorney general’s office says

comments.author: Ever-young
comments.body: The part of the case that surprised me more is the victims who lost up to $100,000 and $300,000 having a job that already made you secure such an amount of money and still be looking for a remote job that requires you to deposit such money to secure the job, for the scammers to get victims that could risk that kind of money. Maybe there could probably be some private and personal data they have on those target victims because the amount that they were scammed individually is not a small amount of money, but I don't blame the victims as they are just looking for better means to secure more income to be able to take care of family, but it's just unfortunate that they fall into the trap of scammers.

comments.author: Maslate
comments.body: Newbies really need to hear this.. thanks for sharing the news.Scammers are getting more creative, using all sorts of strategies just to trick people. For experienced investors, it’s easier to verify if a website is legit, but sadly, some still fall for scams like these. What’s alarming is how much the victims lose, one reportedly lost over $100k, and another over $300k. That’s a massive amount of money. It makes me wonder, how did they manage to deposit such large sums? Was the so-called business opportunity really that convincing to make them risk that much?QuoteThe suit cites seven victims, identified by pseudonyms, residing in New York, Virginia and Florida. One New York victim lost over $100,000, according to the suit. A Florida woman lost over $300,000.

comments.author: Agbamoni
comments.body: I don't understand why someone needs to pay for a job position before they can get the job. Asking someone to pay for a job position before they can get hired is a red flag of scam. Real employers will never charge any candidate to pay for job offers, or interviews or secure a spot for them. I think because of the desperateness of getting a high-paying job, many people are in haste in making decisions without thinking of any possibility the offer might be fake. One way to find out in case next time is the urgent demand of payment from these scammers, another is how mandatory they make the payment aspect, but real companies will not make anything mandatory apart from the job requirements like CV and other documents. In general, anyone looking for a job should research the company or organization that gives them a job offer. For example, they can check if they have any legal agreement with the government, find if they have a physical location, and confirm with others if it really exists. That is one of the easiest ways to identify scam companies.

comments.author: traderethereum
comments.body: I have this text message or WhatsApp message some months ago but I didn't do anything and delete the message immediately. I don't trust about that offers because the offers looks good to be true. I know that if something is like that, it will possibly that message will end with scamming those who join. That is not coming in the crypto but in other aspects so we must be careful to act and delete it immediately. It is better you search for a job in your local area or from your friends.

comments.author: Alone055
comments.body: I mean, how naive do you need to be to fall for something like that? Have you ever heard of a company asking you for money before they give you a job? How does that work? When you get a job, you offer your services in return for money; you are not asked for money so that you can earn more money. When someone asks you for money so that they can give you an opportunity to earn more money, you should understand that it's a trap and that actual jobs and assignments don't work that way.The fact that many people believe earning money online is very easy and anyone can do it is the reason why so many people fall for such scams easily. Once they get an offer, they believe it's real and they will get more money if they spend some because that is how others earn money which isn't true.It's a basic lack of knowledge issue found in people who are eager to earn money but understand nothing, and they ask others only after they get scammed which is unfortunate since nothing can be done when it's late.

comments.author: un_rank
comments.body: Quote from: Alone055 on January 11, 2025, 10:10:35 AMI mean, how naive do you need to be to fall for something like that? Have you ever heard of a company asking you for money before they give you a job? How does that work? When I see things like this, I expect only a few naive people to fall for it, but seeing scammers making away with over $2 million, there has to be a lot more than few people. Some individuals got scammed of $300k using this technique. How does someone with that amount of money fall for a scam like this and risk such a huge amount?We can only try to educate people and protect those that will take precaution.- Jay -

comments.author: Japinat
comments.body: Quote from: Agbamoni on January 11, 2025, 09:44:17 AMI don't understand why someone needs to pay for a job position before they can get the job. Asking someone to pay for a job position before they can get hired is a red flag of scam. The scammer might be really skilled at manipulating people, which is why some actually ended up funding the crypto wallet provided by the "employer." Aside from that obvious red flag, they probably didn’t notice that the offer was too good to be true. That said, not everyone is aware of these types of scams. Even something as simple as checking if a website is newly created, which can easily be done on certain tools, could help avoid falling victim. Unfortunately, many don’t know these basic steps to protect themselves.Quote from: un_rank on January 11, 2025, 10:32:27 AMHow does someone with that amount of money fall for a scam like this and risk such a huge amount?It’s already in the news, so it’s legit - there really have been people scammed. That person probably has a lot of money since they were willing to invest such a huge amount for the promise of attractive commissions and bonuses. Unfortunately, they fell for the trap.

If the victim has invested hundreds of thousands of dollars in cryptocurrency, they should have done some research and know more than the average crypto user. How do these people fall into such scams?I have never heard about scams like this one but I know that in poor countries it is very popular to offer good job benefits to people abroad. For example, some scammers offer people that they'll create a visa for them to work abroad in countries like Dubai. Everyone knows that Dubai is great but people don't know the dark side of Dubai. There is a slavery in UAE. Scammers lie to people, transport them to Dubai and then they become victims of slavery. Poland's visa is also a very popular offer from some scammers. They promise people that they'll have to work in a good environment and their salary will be 100-200 Euro per day but when people move to Poland, they work in factories and farms with bad pay and a high workload.

comments.author: Distinctin
comments.body: Quote from: shield132 on January 11, 2025, 11:06:12 AMI have never heard about scams like this one but I know that in poor countries it is very popular to offer good job benefits to people abroad. Same here, this is the first time I’ve heard of this kind of scam. But it seems different from the example you gave, and I don’t think they’re targeting poor countries. Considering some victims lost amounts like $100k to $300k, it’s unlikely these scammers are aiming at places where even $1k is hard to come by. Their target market must be wealthier individuals or regions where people have access to such large sums.

comments.author: kotajikikox
comments.body: I always try to go by one rule: if it ain't free, it ain't safe The moment money is involved and I am required to deposit even the littlest amount of money in order to get into a project, platform or in this case a job then it is an immediate red flag for me. Even with crypto airdrops who ask you to deposit a certain amount of crypto first without any explanation should be enough of a red flag to you and thus you must avoid at all costs. We are entering a time where being uninformed is no longer a valid excuse. All information is out there in the internet and all you have to do is read be well aware. Be smart if you want to survive in today's world.

comments.author: davis196
comments.body: QuoteAccording to the report, scammers target people by sending unsolicited texts offering jobs with attractive compensation and commissions. However, before starting, they require victims to set up a wallet address and fund it with crypto, supposedly as a form of security. They promise that the funds can be withdrawn along with the commission later on.Yeah, right. I would totally believe every random stranger, who sends me a job offer out of nowhere. Especially the random stranger wanting me to setup a crypto wallet and send funds to that particular crypto wallet. Nothing shady at all.  I can guess that this would be a 2-out of 3 multi-sig wallet and the scammer probably has two keys to unlock the wallet.What kind of "form of security" is this? Does the stranger offering you the job thinks that you will do the job and run away without being paid?  This doesn't make any sense. Some scams are really stupid, but it's sad that there are people, who still become victims of such nonsense scams.

comments.author: freedomgo
comments.body: Quote from: kotajikikox on January 12, 2025, 06:38:09 AMI always try to go by one rule: if it ain't free, it ain't safe Maybe what you mean is, if it’s free, it’s not safe.But in this case, it’s not free as they required an upfront amount to start the work. It might look legit at first, but the victims’ mistake was not verifying if the people they were dealing with were from a legitimate company. They were likely blinded by the attractive offers and got tempted to fund their crypto wallets.Also, they probably lacked basic knowledge about wallets too - why else would they use the hacker’s website to set it up?

comments.author: EluguHcman
comments.body: Why don't the victims have not stumbled about why the job offer is requested crypto wallet in the first place to figure if they were to pay it employees by cryptocurrencies of Fiats.Even while earning by fiats the company would ask you to submit your bank account number or create one for you were you can get paid without the need to make advance payment.With this experience if I was to be in the position to encounter these scamming schemes I would reflect to this one thought.I am personally opted out on any platform that requires me to make an advance payment before my account or profile will be in good use so I don't see convinceable reasons why I would be asked to make payment as follows a job employment unless the employer is deemed to tell me the slot (vacant) is not free but on purchase but then before I will proceed I will find out from right source of it is legitimate or not .

comments.author: Jating
comments.body: It's just crazy how someone can fall for this kind of trick. I mean if you need a job then why would you fund some wallets? It reminds of the ICO post 2017, because during that time because ICO was successful, scammers find a way to trick those investors by asking them to send funds to them before they will get their bounty.But that smells scam from afar, and I don't really understand why there are still individuals who blindly trust anyone in crypto just because they are promise of a big money in exchange. I think this scammers are just rehearsing the same trick all over again.

comments.author: Churchillvv
comments.body: I'm fully aware of this crypto scam. I have came in contact with such offer and perhaps one thing I thought to myself was "did I ever mention I needed job anywhere?" Nah but what was convincing was the pay offer, I couldn't resist it because I could do the work without much stress yet such amount. But when you're asked to login to a very much unknown website, then it's pretty obvious that it's a scam. what I have realised from them all is that the domain of this websites are always very much suspicious, if you examine them carefully. It's also good someone is sharing it here, perhaps others can learn and never to get into their hands especially those of us that offer services on platforms like fiverr.
